descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Language is a familiar part of our everyday lives, but it is also an important topic in philosophy. In this course, we will explore some of the fundamental philosophical issues that surround language. We will investigate what makes a language what it is, by investigating the nature of linguistic meaning, and the range of special actions we can perform in virtue of having a language. We will also investigate what it is to know something so complicated as a human language, by investigating the nature of linguistic rules, and the kinds of cognitive states that comprise knowledge of language. As time permits, we will also examine how the contexts in which we speak influence how we communicate, and the way language is able frame thoughts about the world around us.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will be expected to understand the basic issues and ideas in philosophy of language, and to master a range of tools and techniques used in philosophical approaches to language. They will be expected to able to apply these to specific problems in philosophy of language.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Short papers, class participation, and a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: A.P. Martinich and David Sosa, The Philosophy of Language, Sixth Edition, ISBN 978-0-199-79515-4.
